children.text: This is Latino USA, the radio journal of news and culture.
[Musical transition]
I'm Maria Hinojosa, this time on Latino USA, a focus on Puerto Rico, 100 years after the occupation on the island by the U.S. military.

A hundred years ago, Spain and the United States fought for the naval base. One hundred years later, Spain and the United States are fighting over a telecommunications base. It's the same thing, Maria, nothing has changed.
Even if Puerto Rico were to become a state, the struggle for Puerto Rican independence would continue. So the United States doesn't want to have such a problem in its hands.
We examined the history of the struggle against colonialism in Puerto Rico and the current debate regarding the island's political status.
This and more coming up on this edition of Latino USA.
This is news from Latino USA. I'm David Alvarez.

A federal judge in California says a voter initiative to dismantle bilingual education will go forward. As early as next month, many bilingual classes in California could cease and children could be placed instead in one-year English immersion programs. From San Francisco, Ana Perez reports.

Advocates of bilingual education have suffered a major setback. Judge Charles Leggy of the United States District Court declined to grant a preliminary injunction filed by a number of civil and immigrant rights organizations.
Ron Unz, the proponent of Proposition 227, which was approved in June by a 61 to 30 percent vote, said he was extremely pleased with the verdict.
I think the overwhelming majority of school districts in California will implement our initiative at the beginning of this upcoming school year.
From the beginning we said it would happen, and I do believe now that the last, at least immediate legal hurdle has been met, it will be happening.

These classes will involve teaching children English from the time they start school, unless their parents request otherwise. And I think the overwhelming majority of the parents will be very happy that their children will finally be learning English in California public schools.

Attorneys opposing 227 argue that placing already at-risk children in English immersion programs will put them even further behind. Deborah Escobedo is the attorney representing bilingual education advocates. She said that even if English immersion program was preferred, requiring school districts to put together a program of this magnitude in 60 days is unreasonable.
These are essentially going to be cut and paste programs.

School district after school district said, you know, if you're going to implement any program, you need to have good instructional materials, you need to have adequate curriculum, you need to have trained teachers.
In this time frame, they simply don't have the ability to do that.

Bilingual advocates will determine when and if they will appeal the decision in the next few days. In the meantime, school districts all over California will have to comply with the law. In San Francisco, I'm Ana Perez.
The United Steel Workers Union is suing the U.S. government, challenging the constitutionality of the North American Free Trade Agreement.
The union alleges the trade agreement is actually an economic treaty and should have been passed by a two-thirds majority of the Senate. NPR's Wade Goodwin reports.
The steel workers lawsuit has the potential to throw 40 years of foreign trade agreements into doubt, including America's association with the World Bank and the World Trade Organization.
At issue is this: The Constitution of the United States stipulates that all political and economic treaties must be approved by two-thirds of the Senate.

Since the end of the Second World War, the President and Congress have often finessed this requirement by simply passing trade agreements, not treaties. NAFTA was passed as such by a simple majority of the Congress.

But the steel workers claim, and some constitutional scholars agree that NAFTA is really an economic treaty with Canada and Mexico. The Justice Department has 60 days to respond to the union's lawsuit. For Latino USA, I'm Wade Goodwin.
This is news from Latino USA.

The chairman of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People is calling for Latinos and African Americans to forge a common agenda. The comments were made at the NAACP's annual conference in Atlanta. Susana Capelouto reports.

Most of the six-day event focused on issues important to the Black community, including shaping U.S. policy toward Africa and helping Black farmers who say they are not getting loans because of their race.

But NAACP President Kweisi Mfume made it clear in a speech that Black Americans aren't the only minority still struggling for rights in America. He said even though millions of citizens of African, Hispanic, Asian, and Native American ancestry have accomplished a lot, there is still a great need for improvement.
Mfume said, especially in education, quote, "Black and brown children are not getting the attention they deserve."
The convention also focused on the issue of preserving affirmative action in the U.S. For LatinoUSA, I'm Susana Capilouto in Atlanta.
In Mexico's southern state of Chiapas, heavily armed men have been robbing Indian villages and threatening supporters of the Zapatista movement.
The government, meanwhile, accuses the rebels of killing a member of the ruling party. Frank Contreras reports on recent developments in Chiapas.

The rising violence in Chiapas comes after that state's governor, Roberto Alvarez Guill√©n, put forth what he calls a peace proposal. The governor is calling for transitional governing councils in 32 towns now ruled by rebel governments.

Guillen's plan would also disarm what he calls armed civilian groups. Critics of the governor's plan say that means only Zapatistas since the government continues to deny the presence of paramilitary forces in Chiapas.
The rebels, meantime, broke months of silence with a mocking communique aimed at the government. It reads, "yepa yepa, arriba arriba. It's signed subcomondante Marcos, alias El Speedy Gonzalez."
For Latino USA, this is Franc Contreras in Mexico City.
In Austin, Texas, I'm David Alvarez. You're listening to Latino USA.
I'm Maria Hinojosa. Many nations are born from war, revolution, and diplomacy. But some nations remain stunted, never allowed to mature to their final stature.
Consider the island of Puerto Rico, called Borinquen by its first inhabitants, the Arawak Indians.
Puerto Rico, mapped by Columbus, conquered by Ponce de Leon, and bargained away by Spain in 1898 to the United States at the end of the Spanish-American War.

Puerto Rico was occupied by US troops on July 25, 1898, when a general reassured the islanders that the United States had arrived to promote their prosperity and to bestow upon them the immunities and blessings of the liberal institution of the US government.
One hundred years later, though, the question of national identity still hovers over the island.
Some people call Puerto Rico a colony, others a commonwealth. Some celebrate the association with the United States, others feel it an injustice.

[Singing] Still others endlessly question and analyze the island's political predicament. The debate began during Spain's rule and engaged the great minds of Puerto Rico, The debate began during Spain's rule and engaged the great minds of Puerto Rico, Ram√≥n Emetrio Betances, Eugenia Mar√≠a de Hostos, and Pedro Albizu Campos.
This summer, especially with the symbolism of a century of US rule, island leaders are forced to wrestle with the question of Puerto Rican identity.
We begin today's program with a look at the current ideas shaping the debate about the future of Puerto Rico. Reporter Mario Murillo traveled to the island and has our report.
The popular view of Puerto Rico's current political status is that the island is a commonwealth of the United States.
Although constitutionally this is a misconception, the Supreme Court has ruled that Puerto Rico is in fact a non-incorporated territory.
This means that although the island remains a possession of the United States and is subject to US laws, Washington never intended Puerto Rico to become a state of the Union.
What Congress is now saying with the recent passage of the House bill sponsored by Alaska Republican Don Young is that this colonial relationship is no longer viable.
Governor Pedro Rossello is the leader of the pro-statehood New Progressive Party, or PNP.

After a hundred years, we have a special point in history where the people of Puerto Rico will hopefully have the opportunity of defining after this century-long period what the final political status of Puerto Rico, what the final definition of that transitional period for Puerto Rico will be.
Ironically, the pro-statehood forces have found strange bedfellows in the Puerto Rican Independence Party, or PIP.
Thousands of people waving the green and white flag of the Puerto Rican Independence Party gathered recently in Old San Juan to hear why the PIP is supporting the Young Bill.

The party believes the Republican-controlled Congress is not quite ready to admit Puerto Rico as the 51st state. Therefore, the argument goes, Washington will have no other choice but to grant the island its independence. Ruben Berrios Martinez is the president of the PIP.

Even if Puerto Rico were to become a state, that wouldn't solve the Puerto Rican issue of colonialism, and the struggle for Puerto Rican independence would continue. So the United States doesn't want to have such a problem in its hands.
The complicating matters are the opponents to the current plebiscite legislation, who say the bill is stacked in favor of statehood.
Carlos Vizcarondo of the pro-Commonwealth Popular Democratic Party has been in the Puerto Rican legislature for over eight years.
We're opposing these bills because of the way they've been written. They're keeping off the ballot the majority of the Puerto Rican people who support the current status. It's anti-democratic.

In essence, the Puerto Rican people who want to maintain some kind of connection with the United States are going to have to vote for statehood, while the majority of Puerto Ricans favor a free associated state.
Of the three Puerto Rican members of Congress, only Jose Serrano of New York supports the Young Bill.

Chicago Democrat Luis Gutierrez is adamantly opposed to the plebiscite legislation, as is New York Congressmember Nydia Velazquez, who stated her opposition during the debate on the House floor last March.
I am an American citizen born on the island of Puerto Rico, but I am concerned that a process is about to be imposed on the people of Puerto Rico that is anything but democratic.
Once again, Governor Pedro Rossello.
You know, those people have to make up their mind. This is either a bill that's for statehood or it's a bill that's against statehood. You can't be both.

And when people read the bill itself, they will find that this is a bill that provides for opportunities to choose between three different paths. It starts a movement. It is not the definitive decision.
In decolonization and exercise, are the Americans living in Puerto Rico going to decide what is best for the Puerto Ricans?

Luis Nieves Falcon, coordinator of the Campaign to Free the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners, questions, among other things, whether non-Puerto Ricans on the island will be allowed to participate in a future plebiscite. He also questions the role of the U.S. military in the voting process.

Puerto Rico is a country surrounded by American bases. And I don't think that nobody can deny the psychological impact that has on behavior, any behavior, including electoral behavior of people that are surrounded by military forces.
The Senate Committee on Natural Resources held hearings on the matter in Washington in mid-July, but it's unlikely that the full Senate will take up the issue before the summer recess.
For supporters of the bill, this may be bad news. For opponents, it'll give them some breathing space. For Latino USA, I'm Mario Murillo reporting.
[Musical Transition] What should be the relationship of Puerto Rico to the United States?
These debates echo in Puerto Rican communities here on the mainland as well. Distance does not dissipate the passion.

We turn now to some history from the Puerto Rican community in Chicago, an excerpt now from the documentary, "From San Juan to Humboldt Park, The Two Nations of Puerto Rico." Chicago-based producers Cecilia Weissman and Gary Covino chronicle the emergence of a radical choice among some Puerto Rican activists, that of armed struggle.
[Singing] This song is called Los Motinas de Chicago, The Riots of Chicago.

It tells the story of what happened during the first Puerto Rican Day parade in the summer of 1966. In the middle of the festivities, a fight broke out between two young men. The police moved in, and during the scuffle, one of the Puerto Ricans was shot.
When local residents rushed to the scene, the police unleashed attack dogs. The neighborhood exploded.
For three days, angry crowds burned squad cars, looted white-owned businesses, and fought the police with bricks and rocks.
[Singing] The lyrics say the Puerto Ricans rebelled because they knew that in Chicago there was no justice, and predict the riots will go down in history as the beginning of a new day.

That prediction turned out to be accurate. Three decades later, Humboldt Park residents still cite the riot as the turning point in their community. They say a new spirit emerged, that young people began to feel more pride in being Puerto Rican. And dozens of community organizations sprang up, fighting redlining and arson, working for better schools and better housing.

Oscar Lopez joined right in. He worked with tenants groups and organized several successful rent strikes. Today, he still loves telling the story of one of his favorite actions, against a landlord who refused to make repairs in a dilapidated, cockroach-infested building. Lopez helped the tenants prepare a Christmas gift for the landlord, a beautifully wrapped box full of roaches, which they brought to his suburban home.
The woman who delivered the package, she had this angelic face. She was about 55 years old, and she was a very articulate Puerto Rican woman. You couldn't say no to her.

She went with this real nice package, and this is for you, you know. We're the tenants of the building. We would like to just acknowledge how nice you've been since we were tenants. We're giving you a gift.
All of a sudden, after she takes the box in the house, we heard this scream.
Ahh!
And then she opened up the box, and the roaches just flew out, you know.

Their parents, for the most part, had just wanted to lead quiet lives and assimilate. But for the younger generation, as the 1960s turned into the 70s, it was more important to assert their identity, to find ways to push the United States to adjust to Puerto Ricans and their reality, and not the other way around.
Often, a trip to Puerto Rico was the catalyst. Alicia Rodriguez saved up her money for years to make the journey.
Her whole life, she'd listened to her mother, Josefina, reminisce about the beautiful tropical countryside she had left behind.
Now, Alicia would see it for herself.
When the plane landed, when they opened up the door, and I began to smell...home.
It's almost like how...maybe this is too far-fetched, but people know their mother. People know their mother by their scent. There was a scent that Puerto Rico gave, that I identified with.
And when I stepped off the plane and I stood on Puerto Rican soil, it was the first time in my life I didn't feel a stranger.
And it was a unique experience because I had never felt that. Never felt that.
Alicia's visit changed her life.
While most of the young activists went on with their community work, Alicia, Oscar Lopez, and a few others from the neighborhood took a much more radical path.
They joined an underground guerrilla army called the FALN. The initials stand for the Armed Forces of National Liberation, and they took up arms against the U.S. government.
Their goal was to liberate themselves, their families, friends, and neighbors by waging a war for Puerto Rican independence. It was a decision that for most of them would lead to prison. Oscar Lopez.
It's inseparable. The struggle for education in Chicago, or the struggle for housing in Chicago, is inseparable from the Puerto Rican independence struggle.
And we believed that the only way that we could get Puerto Rico to be independent was through our struggle. And we have to do it, you know. It's the only way.
Hardest hit was New York City. Five bombs exploded in the early morning. Blasts went off outside four banks and the United States Mission to the United Nations.
In Chicago, bombs went off at three locations, the Sears Tower, a bank, and the IBM building.
In Washington, there was a small explosion outside the basement door of the State Department.

I think at that time I felt that's what we had to do, that we had no other recourse. It was an expression, you know what I mean, of anger. It was an expression of pain that the colonial situation in Puerto Rico is intolerable, that we are going to stand up.
We're not going to allow ourselves to be walked upon. So something's got to give. Something's got to give, and sometimes it can't be from a diplomatic arena.

The bomb went off at 1.25 when Wall Street business people were eating a leisurely Friday lunch. when Wall Street business people were eating a leisurely Friday lunch. The Anglers Club and the Francis Tavern next door were both packed with customers. The injured were quickly brought out. There were more than 40.
Between 1974 and 1979, the FALN set off more than 100 bombs in department stores, government buildings, military installations, and corporate headquarters.
Most went off at night when the buildings were empty.
But the FALN's most notorious action was this one, the bombing at the Francis Tavern in New York, which killed five people.
The bomb said they chose the Francis Tavern because it was full of, in their words, reactionary executives.

Eventually, in 1980, the FBI caught up with most of the FALN members. At their trials, they claimed to be prisoners of war. They were tried for numerous crimes, including armed robbery, possession of illegal weapons, and seditious conspiracy, convicted, and sentenced to long terms in prison.
For Oscar Lopez, a sentence of 70 years. Alicia Rodriguez, 85 years.

They've been in jail now for almost two decades. Back in Humboldt Park, many of their friends and relatives and a new generation of young activists are part of a campaign to convince the president to pardon them. It's their only chance to ever leave their prison cells.
From "San Juan to Humboldt Park" was produced by Gary Covino and Cecilia Weissman for station WBEZ in Chicago.

And now joining us on Latino USA from San Juan, Puerto Rico and the studios of WRTU on the island are political analyst Juan Manuel Garcia Passalacqua and attorney Benny Cerezo, former senator for the New Progressive Party and a well-known island figure in the world of Puerto Rican politics. Welcome to both of you.

Now, so far on our program, we have heard a report on the debate over the Young Bill and on the history of the FALN activists in Chicago. You've just witnessed a two-day general strike on the island over the governor's effort to sell off the Puerto Rican telephone company to private investors.

What do both of you have to report on the political mood in Puerto Rico now as some would say the island prepares to commemorate 100 years of US colonialism? Let's start with you, Juan Manuel Garcia Passalacqua.
I assure you, Maria, that the people of Puerto Rico will not vote in a plebiscite until our 15 political prisoners are back home.
So does that, from your perspective, Juan Manuel, kind of capture the sense of the mood of the island?

Absolutely. I have been in touch with Jimmy Carter. He has sent two letters to President Clinton. He has told President Clinton unequivocally that the United States of America cannot hold a plebiscite in Puerto Rico on December 10, 1998 until our 15 political prisoners are home.
Benny Cerezo, from your perspective, what is the mood on the island as you prepare to commemorate 100 years?

Essentially, I think that we are leaving the high points of nationalism in Puerto Rico due to a strike by the workers of the Puerto Rico telephone company, and everybody got behind the symbol of that strike, which is the flag of Puerto Rico.
Well, but how does this mood of nationalism play into the fact that Puerto Rico still does not have its political status resolved?
Well, that's why the Senate agreed to expedite this thing and get it over by December 10.

Because if I can be honest with you, Maria, they are scared, and we cannot say the condition of their scaredness because this is a family station, they are scared, deep, about nationalism in Puerto Rico.

I think that, unfortunately, as you know, I favor statehood for Puerto Rico personally, but I think that in all this debate of the Young Bill, the status that will be trampled and will be defeated, will suffer a major setback is the statehood.

When you push like a madman an item without having the conviction and the knowledge of what you are doing or what to do, the results are unpredictable. And the least the people that have been handling the statehood issue could have imagined is that unprepared as they are, they would meet formidable opponents and people from English First, all the racist people that just detest the Hispanics and don't care to have two Hispanic senators in the Senate and seven or eight representatives in the House.
Statehood for Puerto Rico is impossible because of American racism.

If I could ask both of you to kind of drop your political analyst hats for a minute and talk to me as men, as human beings and from the heart, what does this really mean to each of you when you're talking about commemorating 100 years of the U.S. presence on your island?
And let's start with you, Benny. If you could just talk as a human being, as a man, what does this mean for you?
Well, for all of Puerto Ricans, it means mixed feelings.

On one hand, we have had tremendous development, material development, but for example, I'll give you an example. Yesterday, I was listening to hearings on the Senate and all of a sudden I felt so sad because I have witnessed like Juan Manuel, the last 35, 40 years in politics, in which we have been sometime actors, the other times we have been on the commentators and analysts of the history.

And you see once more the ritual of the people from Puerto Rico going over periodically to Washington and making pleas and begging for justice and begging for the people in Washington to spell out whether they want Puerto Rico and how they want Puerto Rico to be included, that basically I just felt not depressed, but as close to a depression a person can feel because of the sad story of the people of Puerto Rico with the U.S. Congress.

Maria, let me explain it to you. Benny Frankie Serrazzo was the person that spent $400,000 of his own money to defend statehood in Washington in the 1989-1991 process of his own pocket. And this is the man we have next to us and that's what he's telling you.
Well, Juan Manuel, from your perspective again, from your soul, what does it mean to you to be commemorating 100 years of the U.S. presence on the island of Puerto Rico?
Maria, irony, irony. A hundred years ago, Spain and the United States fought for an naval base.
One hundred years later, Spain and the United States are fighting over a telecommunications base.
TISA, owned by the Spanish government, is fighting against GTE, owned by the Pentagon, for ruling our telecommunications base.
It's the same thing, Maria. Nothing has changed. It was an naval base then, it's a telecommunications base, a hundred years later.
The only difference, Maria, is that a hundred years ago, Maria, I assure you, and you know me, a hundred years ago we were spectators.

One hundred years later, we were in the streets saying, we count, we're a nation, we're not going to settle for a Spanish-American war on telecommunications unless we're in. And thanks God, man, that strike was an enormous success.
And all I'm going to say at the end is on this 25th of July of 1998, America's folly in the Caribbean has become evident. Cuba and Puerto Rico will survive. American imperialism will end.
Well, thanks very much for speaking with us.
Political analyst Juan Manuel Garcia Passaalaqcua and attorney and former Puerto Rican Senator Beni Franqui-Cerezo, they spoke with us from San Juan, Puerto Rico. Muchas gracias to both of you.
And for this week, this has been Latino USA, the radio journal of news and culture.
